musicalLanguage.description: One of the oldest melodies still in active performance, dating to the English Renaissance (c. 1580). Written in 3/4 time with a distinctive minor-key waltz feel, it moves between the natural minor and the raised 7th (D# leading tone), creating the characteristic 'ancient' sound. Also known as 'What Child Is This?' in its Christmas carol form.
musicalLanguage.structure: A (verse) - A (repeat) - B (chorus/refrain, 'Alas, my love') - B (repeat). Simple binary form.
keyMoments: The opening E minor descent: sets the melancholy, ancient mood
The raised D# in the melody: the modal inflection that gives Greensleeves its character
The B section ('Alas, my love'): the melody rises to its highest point, the emotional peak
teachingGoals: Minor key melody with modal inflections (natural vs harmonic minor)
Simple left-hand accompaniment patterns in triple meter
Phrasing across bar lines — the melody doesn't always start on beat 1
styleTips: Feel the waltz — gentle emphasis on beat 1, lighter on 2 and 3
The melody should sing — connect the notes legato
Keep the accompaniment simple and quiet, like a lute
This is Renaissance music — restraint and elegance, not Romantic drama
